10.1016/j.rser.2023.114235 Fig. 1 Energy Management for Smart Spaces (EMSS) framework: Architecture. • Decision engine layer: The output of the data fusion engine, i.e., fused data with high-level features serves as the input to the decision engine. Later, the decision engine applies different artificial intelligence algorithms to the input data & derive patterns and insights on the energy consumption. Such data patterns and insights are then used to generate recommendations and alerts for the considered energy optimization use cases. The generated recommendation and alerts are (i) published as recommendations/alerts to the data visualization layer, (ii) stored in the database along with the sensor data from the data pipeline and fused data, and (iii) passed to controller/user for further actions. The old data (sensor data, fused data, user actions, and recommendations) are moved from the database to the data repository as archives. • Data visualization layer: The data and recommendations stored in the database are used by the data visualization layer to present energy analytics on the energy consumption and energy bills at required granularities. It also provides an interactive smart space dashboard specifically designed for energy optimization controls through detailed analysis on energy consumption and enforcing smart recommendations (control setpoints of HVACs, fan speed, indoor air quality, gas leaks, security controls, and turn ON/OFF/MODE appliances). The user actions on the recommendations are saved in the database and sent to the actuators for the initiation of appropriate controls. Advancements in Internet of Energy (IoE) technologies drive the development of several energy efficient frameworks for better energy optimization, economic savings, safety, and security in smart homes. However, certain challenges such as real-time operational data for each micro-moment, proper application of data fusion techniques, and end-to-end computing and deployment architecture prevent the establishment of an effective energy-efficient framework to provide personalized energy-saving recommendations. This work presents energy management for smart spaces (EMSS), the proposed energy efficiency framework implemented in an edge-cloud computing platform that fuses data from heterogeneous data sources (environmental sensors, camera, plug data, etc.) at appropriate data fusion levels and process them to generate actionable, explainable, personalized, and persuasive recommendations at the right moment. The user response to the generated recommendations triggers the actuators to perform respective energy-saving actions and provide more personalized future recommendations. Further, SMARTHome - a data generation framework based on configurable scenario files and a set of software codes was proposed to generate synthetic data with respect to different building types and micro-moments. The functionalities of the EMSS (device and user registration), user dashboard, analytics, and energy-saving recommendations were made accessible to the user through web and mobile applications. The validation analysis of the EMSS was performed by (i) comparative analysis of the machine learning and deep learning algorithms used by the decision engine to generate energy-saving recommendations and (ii) benchmarking of EMSS based on the taxonomy of data fusion-based energy efficiency frameworks for smart homes. In particular, buildings in urban areas consume more than 40 % of the overall energy demand and account for more than 50 % of the associated carbon emissions [3]. The energy consumption of the building sector is expected to rise by 1.3 % per year on average in Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries and more than 2 % per year on average for non-OECD from 2018 to 2050 [4]. Further, unexpected circumstances like COVID-19 pandemic (social distancing measures, e-learning, remote working, etc) have temporarily shifted the energy demand from commercial buildings to residential areas which has led to increased usage, billing, and economic impact on residential customers [5]. Buildings as the primary energy consumers and contributor of carbon emissions, it is highly significant to look out for strategies and technologies to reduce energy consumption and enhance the performance of the buildings thereby achieving the long-term goals on energy efficiency, environmental and climate change [6]. Recent research and development initiatives focus on the design of (i) nearly zero energy buildings (nZEBs): employs energy management systems, sustainable and renewable energy sources, and (ii) energy-saving smart Internet of Energy (IoE) technologies: uses Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence, big data analytics, edge/cloud computing platform, and behavioural analytics [7]. Due to the practical implications in developing nZEBs such as high deployment cost and challenges in applying to conventional buildings, innovative energy-saving solutions based on IoE are preferred and adopted by the energy providers, end-users, and policymakers to progress towards energy savings, energy security, and carbon reduction in building sectors [8]. Smart IoE technologies have significant role in the design of a powerful energy efficiency ecosystem for remote acquisition and control, i.e., collecting data on indoor and outdoor ambient conditions, appliance energy consumption, end-user habits/activities, and preferences [9]. About 20 % energy savings can be achieved by tailoring different energy-efficient measures targeting the end-user behaviour thereby, helping them to understand their energy consumption patterns and improve their consumption behaviour [10]. Energy efficiency frameworks based on behavioural change involve analyzing the energy consumption footprints and associated contextual information to provide the end-users with tailored recommendations on optimizing their energy usage to achieve greater economic and ecological benefits. Several energy efficiency ecosystems based on end-user behavioural change have been designed using information and communication technologies (ICT) such as IoT technologies, smart sensors, smart meters, big data analytics (data aggregation and data fusion), artificial intelligence techniques, and edge/cloud computing platform to provide personalized energy-saving recommendations to the end-users. The identification of common energy consumption activities in a household (cooking, sleeping, relaxing, bathing, and working on computers), user interests, and associated costs help to investigate the impact of energy behaviour of the user on domestic energy consumption. To achieve the same, recent studies use the concept of micro-moments, which is the energy consumption behaviour of the user throughout the day at different time intervals [11]. For example, the user performs cooking activity between 12:00 p.m. to 1:00 p.m., during which electrical appliances like microwave oven, kettle, exhaust chimneys, mixer grinder, blender, and dishwasher are active and consume about 20 kWh. These micro-moments provide rich contextual information on energy consumption and are usually coupled with environmental data (temperature, humidity, occupancy, and luminosity). Though there has been a significant progress in the development of energy efficiency framework for smart home, the major challenges that prevents the establishment of an effective ones are mostly related to, (i) benchmark datasets: unavailability of open access repositories containing existing datasets collected for different building types with respect to various energy-saving scenarios and user micro-moments, (ii) real time operational data: it is difficult to obtain real time data with respect to the building type and user-specific activities for different energy optimization scenarios; smaller set of user actions/ratings (accept/reject/no response) for the generated recommendations (data sparseness) and lack of user actions for new recommendations (cold start problem) results in unreliable recommendations and user dissatisfaction, (iii) data formats: inability to handle structured (numeric data from sensors) and unstructured data (image and audio data from camera and noise sensors) (iv) data fusion: ignoring its broader scope to generate meaningful recommendations, it is mostly used to handle the uncertainty in the data measurements and improve the quality of the extracted information, (v) third party frameworks: integration of the energy efficiency framework with third party recommendation system, analytics, and visualization platform, (vi) validation of the energy efficiency framework: due to the unavailability of the benchmark datasets and evaluation toolkits, it has been difficult to validate the new energy efficiency framework designed for smart spaces. Fusion-based recommender frameworks adopting data fusion and sub-recommendation fusion schemes (item fusion method [12], multi-modal fusion [13], multi-level fusion [14], matrix factorization [15], joint-representation learning paradigm [16]) have gained popularity to provide end-users with timely and personalized energy-saving recommendations. However, such systems use a batch training process that ignores the dynamics in the user preferences, an important aspect in the real-time deployment of the recommender system. To summarize, this work focuses on the development of an efficient recommendation platform that consciously fuses the environment, energy consumption, user feedback, and user habit data to generate actionable, explainable, personalized, and persuasive recommendations at the right moment. To overcome the challenges in the state-of-the-art energy efficiency frameworks for smart homes this work presents energy management for smart spaces (EMSS), an end-to-end energy efficiency framework for smart spaces. Section 4 concludes the study with future directions. 2 Energy management for smart spaces (EMSS) framework The major objective of EMSS, a multi-sensor data fusion platform for energy optimization in smart spaces is to provide comfortable & energy-efficient living spaces and workspaces through smart recommendations for optimal appliance usage and indoor environment control. To achieve the same, EMSS employs a combination of different indoor and outdoor environmental sensors, plug-level sensors, smart meters, actuators for data acquisition, smart data fusion approaches, intelligent algorithms, and visualizations to derive energy-efficient recommendations. Fig. 1 depicts the architecture and workflow of EMSS for energy optimization in smart spaces such as homes, workspaces, industries, and commercial buildings. The architecture of EMSS consists of four primary layers and detailed functionalities of each layer are. • Data ingestion layer: In general, smart spaces are equipped with different types of sensors such as indoor and outdoor environmental sensors, smart meters, plug-level sensors, CCTV, gas, proximity, and motion sensors to sense and monitor the environment at different granularities. The data ingestion layer acquires the real-time operational data from the various sensors deployed at the considered smart spaces and feeds them into appropriate data pipelines (sensor, plug, audio, and video) for further processing. • Data fusion layer: The data from the different sensors deployed across the smart space are used as inputs to the data fusion engine. A series of data preprocessing and fusion techniques were applied to the input data fed to the data fusion engine, which results in fused data with high-level features. For example, sensor readings from the multiple temperature ( T 1 , T 2 , … , T n ) , light ( L 1 , L 2 , … , L n ) , humidity ( H 1 , H 2 , … , H n ) , and C O 2 ( C O 2 1 , C O 2 2 , … , C O 2 n ) , sensors are processed by the data fusion layer to provide the fused data, i.e., fused_temperature, fused_light, fused_humidity, and fused_ C O 2 . The data fusion layer performs (i) low-level data fusion: fuses the datapoints from multiple sensors, measuring the same variable, and (ii) mid-level data fusion: fuses data from different type of sensors at the same time to derive high-level information from the low-level fused features. 2.1 Energy optimization in smart homes 2.1.1 Sensor data The input data streams for energy optimization in smart homes are generated by the smart home simulator csv module (Refer Section 3.1). The synthetic operational data of the smart home are fed as inputs to the data fusion engine through respective data pipelines. The data streams comprise of (i) Environmental sensor data: indoor and outdoor environmental conditions of the smart home using temperature, humidity, light, C O 2 , and gas sensors, (ii) Energy consumption data: energy consumption of the appliances (TV, ACs, light, washing machine, dish washer, and microwave oven) using plug-level sensors and smart meters, and (iii) Occupancy detection data: room occupancy status using motion sensors and camera. 2.1.2 Different levels of data fusion Fig. 2 depicts the different levels of data fusion, i.e., low-level, mid-level and high-level in the data fusion platform for energy optimization in smart homes. The goal of different levels of fusion is to get the optimized temperature, humidity, and occupancy value for energy optimization. The data fusion occurs as, (i) Feed the data from the multiple temperature, humidity, motion, and camera sensors as an input to the data fusion engine through the respective data pipelines, (ii) Fuse multiple data points of the same sensor type to get the low-level fused humidity, temperature, motion, camera which is further used for mid-level fusion, (iii) Fuse the data from the motion sensor and camera to derive occupancy, and (iv) Fuse the mid-level fused features and occupancy using the high-level fusion algorithms. The low-level fusion focuses on the accurate and reliable sensing or measurement of the input data which is to be processed by various components of the data fusion platform. The input to the low-level fusion algorithm is provided by the multiple sensors deployed in the smart home to record the environment variables. In the current setup, three sensors have been deployed to sense each contextual factor in each room, however, the number of sensors can be greater or lesser than three. For example, a set of three temperature sensors ( T e m p 1 , T e m p 2 , T e m p 3 ) have been deployed in each room (living hall, room 1, room 2, and room 3) of the smart home space to record temperature values. The mean of the three sensor values for each contextual feature was calculated and used as fused sensor value. However, this method may not be the most accurate method because, • Out of three sensor values, one or more of the values could be skewed. • Conditional probability based on the past events, where one sensor is value is in specific range while the other sensor measurements are in different range. To handle such issues, the probabilistic weights of the sensor values are determined by the low-level fusion algorithm. Based on the past events, if there exist such occurrences in the historical data, the low-level fusion algorithm assigns high probabilistic weights to the sensor value even though its range is different than other two sensors. Mid-level fusion is a technique that fuses the results from the low-level fusion module to get high-level features. For example, the mid-level fusion fuses the inference from the camera (motion detection module + motion sensor data) to detect occupancy. Bernoulli Naives Bayes and random forest algorithms were used to perform mid-level fusion. It integrates information from multiple sources to gain a comprehensive understanding of the environment. It is more complex and computationally intensive when compared to the low and mid-level data fusion. The decision engine performs high-level fusion and generates alerts/recommendations based on the data collected from the sensors. This work models the problem of generating right recommendations at right moment to increase the probability of user acceptance as a time-series classification task. To achieve the same, a set of artificial intelligence techniques such as decision trees, random forest, and LSTM have been used by the decision engine to generate accurate recommendations with the low-level and mid-level fused data from the data fusion layer. For each energy optimization use case, the fused data at a given time ( T S i = ( F S t 1 , F S t 2 , … , F S t n ) ) , aggregated fused data of the previous time intervals ( T S j = ( F S t − 1 1 , F S t − 1 2 , … , F S t − 1 m ) ) and user actions on the previous recommendations generated ( T S k = ( A 1 , A 2 , … , A m ) ) are fed as inputs to the AI models. The user actions can either be ‘0’ (No response), ‘+1’ (Positive response), and ‘-1’ (Negative response). The output value ( O t = f ( T S i , T S j , T S k ) ) of the model is ‘0’ for ‘No recommendation’ and ‘1’ for ‘Recommendation generated at time t’. 2.2 Energy optimization use cases and recommendations The fused data obtained from appropriate application of different levels of data fusion on the input data streams from various data pipelines are used as inputs by the decision engine module to generate energy-saving alerts/recommendations for each energy optimization use case. The implementation of EMSS framework for energy optimization in smart homes involves four main energy optimization use cases, namely (i) appliance level energy management, (ii) light management, (iii) AC management, and (iv) indoor air quality management. The alerts/recommendations generated by the decision engine for each room are published as events and consumed by the controller. Table 2 presents the input, output, and generated recommendations for the four energy optimization use cases. Recommendations are of two types, namely (i) instantaneous: recommendations generated at the time when an event occurs, e.g., recommendation on AC temperature set point or generating gas leak alert, and (ii) temporal: recommendations generated when an event occurs over a specified time interval. e.g., if the living room TV is ON without occupancy for over 10 min, an alert would be generated to turn OFF the TV. • Appliance-level energy management: This scenario deals with controlling the appliances such as washing machine, ACs, dishwasher, microwave oven, and TVs based on the occupancy and energy consumption data from the plug level sensors and smart meters. The outputs of the decision engine are (i) graphs and analytics: weekly consumption graph, occupancy graph of each room, occupancy vs. energy consumption, appliances with highest energy consumption, and appliance level energy consumption, and (ii) alerts/recommendations: switch ON/OFF the devices based on the occupancy, temperature, and humidity. • Light management: The decision engine processes the input data, i.e., fused feature (light, light plug data, occupancy) and generate an alert/recommendation for the user. For example, alerts to switch ON/OFF the lights based on the occupancy. Fig. 3 provides the workflow of the EMSS framework for energy optimization in smart homes. The ingestion layer comprises of sensor, plug, and video pipeline to provide necessary operational data of the smart home. The data from the different sensors deployed across the smart home are used as inputs to the data fusion engine. The data fusion layer in the data fusion block process the data from the multiple sensors (temperature ( T 1 , T 2 , … , T n ) , light ( L 1 , L 2 , … , L n ) , humidity ( H 1 , H 2 , … , H n ) , and C O 2 sensors) to provide accurate fused data (fused_temperature, fused_light, fused_humidity, and fused_ C O 2 ). The video pipeline data is fed as the input to the object detection module to detect the occupancy. The sensor data and the output of the object detection module, i.e., occupancy is fed as the input to the mid-level fusion to provide the occupancy count and status. The fused sensor data, plug load data, occupancy count and occupancy status are given as an input to the decision engine. A set of artificial intelligence models such as decision trees, random forest, and LSTM [33] are used by the decision engine for classification tasks, i.e., binary classification (0 - ‘No recommendation at time t’ and 1 – ‘Provide recommendation at time t’). The decision engine continuously trains the AI models for each user and energy optimization use case to provide energy-efficient actionable recommendations in real-time, thereby promoting energy-savings. For each energy optimization use case considered in this study, the inputs from various data pipelines are processed by the data fusion layer and decision engine layer to generate energy-saving actionable recommendations. The recommendations generated by the decision engine are (i) actionable: recommendations are based on the fused IoT data, (ii) explainable: recommendations are self-explainable to inform the user about the factors that triggered the recommendation (e.g., AC is ON without occupancy, appliances running for a longer period, and so on), and (iii) persuasive: each recommendation informs the user about the economic and ecological benefits such that it drives the user towards accepting the recommended actions, and (iv) personalized: the user actions on each recommendation is saved to learn the user behavior with respect to the contextual features and tailor the future recommendations to be context and user-sensitive. 2.3 End-to-end integration of the data fusion platform for smart homes Due to the unavailability of real time data that satisfies the data requirements of the smart home space, the concept of ‘digital twin’ is used to generate the required data using a smart home simulator. More details on the smart home simulator designed to generate synthetic data for smart homes are provided in Section 3.1. To the best of the knowledge, benchmark datasets available at various data repositories do not contain the required parameters/fields related to the environmental and appliance level aesthetics of the smart homes. Specifically, available datasets do not include the real-time operational data generated for various micro-moments in the smart homes such as cooking, sleeping, and washing. Such benchmark datasets cannot be used to train the models designed for energy optimization in smart home as. • The exact real-time smart home environment cannot be mimicked throughout the data collection period (especially several months to years). • The nature of the appliances installed at the home and their operation schedule remains unique for each user. • Modelling the user behaviour is too complex as it is highly impacted by the environmental and psychological factors. • Data for different micro-moments or scenarios (e.g., energy consumption during different levels of occupancy, cooking, etc.) of the smart home user activity is difficult to generate. • Unavailability of the data from multiple sensors measuring the same physical entity (most basic data requirement for data fusion models). • High cost and time related factors involved in setting up the environment. This work presents SMARTHome, synthetic data generation framework designed using Python libraries to address the challenges in generating data from real-time environments and available benchmark energy consumption datasets. For this study, SMARTHome generates appliance-level energy consumption (plug load and smart meter), environmental (temperature, humidity, C O 2 , gas), and occupancy (proximity, motion and camera) related data for a smart home with three rooms (Room1, Room2, and Room3), one living hall (Hall1), one kitchen (Kitchen1), two bathrooms (Bathroom1 and Bathroom2), two sit outs (Balcony1 and Balcony2), one backyard (Backyard1), and one entrance lobby (Entrancelobby1) at per minute granularity. The scenarios for four-energy optimization use cases are, 1. Appliance-level energy optimization: (i) Room is VACANT and appliances are RUNNING and (ii) plug load data of the active appliances. 2. Light management: (i) Lights are ON and the natural outdoor lighting is sufficient and (ii) lights are ON and room is VACANT. 3. AC management: (i) AC is ON and the outdoor temperature is in the comfortable level, (ii) AC is ON and room is VACANT, and (iii) plug load data of the AC. 4. Indoor air quality management: Indoor air quality index is beyond healthy and critical levels. In addition, nature of occupancy (vacant, intermittent vacant, less vacant, and highly vacant), time at which the appliances are turned ON/OFF and related impact on the indoor environment and temporal aspects of an activity (weekday/weekend/hour of the day) need to be considered while modelling different smart home scenarios. Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) [2] is the most common resampling technique used to handle the class imbalance problem, which generates new samples by looking at the feature space of the minority class data points and its k nearest neighbors. The class labels (recommendation) of the energy optimization use cases are binary class labels (‘0’: No recommendation generated and ‘1’: Recommendation is generated). The generated dataset for energy optimization use cases has a class imbalance problem with more records for label ‘0’ (10,000 records) than label ‘1’ (500 records). Therefore, SMOTE oversampling technique was applied to generate new samples based on the data records of the minority class. It is highly important to handle such cases so that they do not affect the performance of the upstream data fusion pipelines. The data is sorted in increasing order and split into, (i) Quartile 1 (Q1): 25th percentile of the data (median of the dataset), (ii) Quartile 2 (Q2): 50th percentile of the data (median of n smallest data points), and (iii) Quartile 3 (Q3): 75th percentile of the data (median of n largest data points). The PCC based feature selection technique evaluates the feature subsets based on the highly correlated features. The value of PCC lies in the range of [−1, 1], (i) closer to 0 or 0: weaker or no correlation, (ii) 1: stronger correlation and (iii) -1: stronger negative correlation. The server API is deployed in the server to communicate with the locally exposed API end points (iot_api) in the edge devices. Whenever, the server API wants to communicate with the edge device, it drafts a request message with respect to the API endpoint and sends it to the request pipeline of the home ID. The edge device utility constantly listens to the request pipeline and once a message is received, it requests the appropriate local API to perform the intended action. On successful processing and response from the local API, the edge device utility drafts a response message with the request ID, API response, and response dictionary which is sent through the response pipeline allocated to the home ID. For each request ID, the server API constantly listens to the response pipeline for 4 s. If the server API receives response for the request ID within 4 s, it cross-checks the received response with the request ID, else it returns an error message (time out). The decision engine module uses LSTM network to generate actionable, personalized, persuasive, and actionable energy-saving recommendations for the four-energy optimization use cases, (i) light management, (ii) AC management, (iii) appliance-energy management, and (iv) indoor air quality management. For experimentation purposes, random forest, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, decision trees, and LSTM were used to generate the energy-saving recommendations for each energy optimization use case. However, LSTM was used in the decision engine since it outperformed the other classifiers in terms of various classification metrics (Accuracy (%): 98.60–99.85; Precision (%): 98.54–99.54; Recall (%): 98.10–99.10; and F1-Score (%): 98.32–99.32). The inputs and the recommendations generation for each energy optimization use case are. (i) Light management: To prevent the unnecessary light usage, the data streams from the indoor and outdoor light sensors (illuminance), occupancy, status of the light switch, and user actions on the previous recommendation are fed as inputs to the decision layer to generate the recommendations, (i) Turn ON the light when the room is occupied, (ii) Turn OFF the light when the room is unoccupied, (iii) Turn OFF the light and open the screen when the room is occupied, and sufficient natural lighting is present, and (iv) Increase/decrease the indoor luminosity based on the outdoor light intensity. (ii) AC management: The data streams from the indoor and outdoor environmental sensors, occupancy, AC setpoint, AC plug, thermal comfort index and user actions on the previous recommendation are fed as input to the decision engine to generate the recommendations, (i) Turn ON the AC with the recommended setpoint when the room is occupied. and the indoor thermal comfort index is ‘Less comfortable’ and ‘Uncomfortable’, (ii) Turn OFF the AC when the room is unoccupied, (iii) Turn OFF the AC and suggest the user to open the window when the outdoor temperature is lesser than the indoor temperature, and (iv) Set the AC to the recommended setpoint based on the indoor thermal comfort index when the room is occupied. (iii) Appliance-energy management: The data streams from the plug sensors, indoor and outdoor environmental sensors, occupancy, and user actions on the previous recommendation are fed as input to the decision engine to generate the recommendations, (i) Turn OFF the appliance when the room is unoccupied, and (ii) Turn OFF the long running energy consuming appliances (iv) Indoor air quality management: The data streams from the indoor and outdoor environmental sensors, air purifier plug, occupancy, and user actions on the previous recommendation are fed as input to the decision engine to generate following recommendations, (i) Turn ON the air purifier when the air quality index of the room is above the healthy level, (ii) Turn ON the air purifier and open the windows when gas leak is detected, and (iii) Turn OFF the air purifier when the air quality index of the room is in healthy level. The LSTM network process the related information of the recent historical observations for every 20 min (AC management & indoor air quality management) and 10 min (appliance-energy management and light management) to derive appropriate energy-saving recommendations. A real-world experiment was carried out in a smart home with five users for the considered energy optimization use cases on light management, AC management, appliance energy management, and indoor air quality management. The possible recommendations are rendered and displayed to the user in an actionable, explainable, economical, contextual and user-sensitive manner. For example, the recommendation tile for AC management consists of: (i) actionable: create recommendation “Turn OFF the AC and open the Window in the living room”) based on the input sensor data (AC plug load and setpoint, temperature and humidity (indoor and outdoor); (ii) explainable: “Turn OFF the AC and open the Window in the living room”. The outdoor temperature is lower than the indoor temperature; (iii) economical: Taking the action to Turn OFF the AC and open the window as the outdoor temperature is lower than the indoor temperature will provide an economic benefit of $2.5 and ecological benefit of reducing 0.02 kg of carbon emissions in the monthly energy bill; and (iv) contextual and user-sensitive: user actions (accept/reject/ignore) on the recommendations generated when the outdoor temperature is lower than the indoor temperature will be saved and used to tailor the future recommendations of the user. Certain facets of the EMSS framework that prevents a fair comparative analysis with the state-of-the-art smart home optimization techniques in terms of data and intelligence algorithm are, (i) heterogeneous data sources: data from environmental sensors, occupancy sensors, and plug sensors; data are collected and fused from more than three sensors of same type, i.e., fused temperature data in the living room is derived from the three temperature sensors; (ii) energy optimization use cases: data generated for the considered energy optimization use cases is highly dependent on the configuration of the scenarios defined in the SMARTHome synthetic data generation module; and (iii) data fusion levels: data fusion applied to the high volume data generated by the heterogeneous data sources occurs at different levels, i.e., low-level fusion (environmental sensors), mid-level fusion (occupancy sensors), and high-level fusion (recommendation). Research challenges with respect to the design of appropriate energy optimization scenarios and use cases for the accurate generation of synthetic data from SMARTHome and the time taken to learn from the user actions to generate timely and reliable energy-saving recommendations. 4 Conclusion With the design of EMSS, web and mobile application for energy optimization in smart spaces, novelty of the work lies in the (i) a scalable and reliable end-to-end data fusion platform, (ii) synthetic data generation framework to mimic the real-world scenario and use cases in different smart spaces, (iii) different data fusion levels and algorithms, (iii)generate actionable, explainable, personalized, and persuasive recommendations at the right moment, (iv) web and mobile applications to drive and instigate the energy conscious behaviour of the user, and (v) EMSS energy efficiency framework built with latest technologies in Kafka, Apache Spark, dockers, MongoDB, React, and Django on edge-cloud computing infrastructure. The practical implication of this study is to instigate the energy-efficiency-driven end user behaviour to promote long-term energy efficiency, economic and ecological goals by providing efficient control and optimization of the smart spaces with reliable recommender algorithms, AI techniques, and sensor/smartphone infrastructure. The limitations of the EMSS are two-folds, (i) number of sensors and appliances, energy optimization scenarios and respective energy-saving recommendations should be carefully designed prior to the execution of the SMARTHome for synthetic data generation, and (ii) time required for the system to adapt to the user profile for the generation of timely and appropriate energy-saving recommendations based on the user actions and behaviour during the recent time intervals. The future scope of the work includes the exploration of advanced technologies (blockchains and cryptocurrencies) and visualization tools to motivate end-user behavioural change. coredata.dc:description: Advancements in Internet of Energy (IoE) technologies drive the development of several energy efficient frameworks for better energy optimization, economic savings, safety, and security in smart homes. However, certain challenges such as real-time operational data for each micro-moment, proper application of data fusion techniques, and end-to-end computing and deployment architecture prevent the establishment of an effective energy-efficient framework to provide personalized energy-saving recommendations. This work presents energy management for smart spaces (EMSS), the proposed energy efficiency framework implemented in an edge-cloud computing platform that fuses data from heterogeneous data sources (environmental sensors, camera, plug data, etc.) at appropriate data fusion levels and process them to generate actionable, explainable, personalized, and persuasive recommendations at the right moment. The user response to the generated recommendations triggers the actuators to perform respective energy-saving actions and provide more personalized future recommendations. Further, SMARTHome - a data generation framework based on configurable scenario files and a set of software codes was proposed to generate synthetic data with respect to different building types and micro-moments. The functionalities of the EMSS (device and user registration), user dashboard, analytics, and energy-saving recommendations were made accessible to the user through web and mobile applications. The validation analysis of the EMSS was performed by (i) comparative analysis of the machine learning and deep learning algorithms used by the decision engine to generate energy-saving recommendations and (ii) benchmarking of EMSS based on the taxonomy of data fusion-based energy efficiency frameworks for smart homes.
